Well BTC vs XAU takes fiat money printing out of the equation. Obviously Bitcoin has a ways to go, but there was a 100x increase from $200 to $20k in the last market cycle. This cycle from about $3400 bottom of cycle, we'll see what happens. Another 100x would make it very close.

Plus bitcoin is early so there is more upside, speculative on adoption. Gold is still moderately volatile and +/- flat after adjusting for inflation, and is itself a long term store of value and geo-political uncertainty hedge is my take.

Not that many people hold gold. I used to have some gold ETF units some years ago (I asked for 100% physical, non re-hypothecated). I don't think it's so hard to get more Bitcoin HODLers than gold, it's easier to buy, sell and use, and works at a distance, instant assay, better!

Digital gold (BTC) vs physical gold (XAU), thats the real hyperbitcoinization metric flippening to track. (Hyperbitcoinization may involve a mix of Bitcoin adoption, Fiat demonetization/hyperinflation and flight to safety, so XAU is a better comparator.)

They can opt in to it. Physical gold and cash have the same properties through the ages that Bitcoin has but better. Society figures out it's tradeoffs, in adapting to new improved technology. #Bitcoin is better hard money tech, and that's a good thing for the world.

Not sure. In my opinion we need more size and ideally verification cost optimization. But the Confidential Transactions related crypto has progressed surprisingly fast so far. You can try CT out on #LiquidNetwork #Bitcoin sidechain with @Blockstream green wallet on Android & iOS

But ultimately "Bitcoin is" and we should not mis-sell it to users with incompatible use cases as they may then argue to degrade the core properties and cause the bigger picture to get derailed. We can't build a new gold standard on a digital tulip or insecure micro-payment pivot

The properties are pretty ideal money which is a financial rock many other use cases can be built on. We'll see if Bitcoin reaches digital gold adoption equilibrium as competitor to physical gold or blows on past to new global gold standard for world money per @saifedean's book.

I think really you want users who come to learn and care about Bitcoin for it's differentiated properties. If it is oversold to people with other use cases they may end up argueing to change it's properties. Permissionless, censorship resistant, digital-gold based ecash.

The liquid networks code is based on bitcoin-core code, with patches for extra features like confidential transactions, native assets, federated block-signing and 2-way peg of BTC<->L-BTC. The federation block-signers have hardware security modules for key signing.

Liquid is a side-chain, L-BTC is pegged BTC which is network exchangeable for L-BTC. The Liquid side-chain is federated, and the federated nodes are exchanges, market-makers, prop trading companies, Bitcoin payment processors. The federation does block-signing not mining.

This to me is the Bitcoin holy-grail missing crypto. And I see reasonable prospect of getting there mid-term as some experimental-crypto SNARK variants are already close. Doing it with conservative crypto is harder, but the progress with Bullet Proofs was startlingly good & fast.

I would prefer fungibility at Bitcoin layer1. I think it will get there. The main hold up is the no trapdoor, no trusted setup, conservative crypto assumption building blocks are not quite there yet, though the trend with Bullet Proofs etc is good and progress surprisingly fast.

I think even the funding can be p2p addressed without alts in layer2. If Bitcoin R&D ecosystem had 5% of the money burned in alts, ICOs crypto could pull ahead much faster. We largely know what to do and where to R&D invest on code, applied algo research.

Bitcoin itself and the ecosystem of libraries, wallets, hardware, layer2s pulls ahead due to the continuous centre of gravity of long-term focussed dev interest. One grey area is funding, but innovation without speculation is a better experience once the market prices history.

Or bitcoin layer2 dev-kits - sidechain programmability should converge to be easier to add features than patching Bitcoin code and be more maintainable as it tracks Bitcoin improvement. Bitcoin libraries, networking, modularity, layering are all improving and by a fast pace,

R & D is fine, I got actively involved with Bitcoin some years ago to focus on improving it's crypto-fungibility. That's where confidential transactions (and other crypto ideas) came from. There is still scope to improve efficiency and I really hope to to see adopted in Bitcoin.

IMO Bitcoin should add crypto-fungibility into layer1 as soon as secure, robust and efficient-enough crypto tech exists to do it. FYI much of the conservative security assumption crypto R&D on that is being done by ... bitcoin protocol developers and applied cryptographers.
